head.title: Many Crash as Roads Become Rinks in Sudden Morning Cold Snap

hedline.hl1: Many Crash as Roads Become Rinks in Sudden Morning Cold Snap

block.p: Sudden formations of ice sheets turned roads into billiard tables yesterday morning, causing cars and trucks to bang into and bounce off each other in multi-vehicle fender-benders across Westchester County and northern New Jersey and into the Southern Tier of New York, the police reported.
There were no serious injuries.

Sudden formations of ice sheets turned roads into billiard tables yesterday morning, causing cars and trucks to bang into and bounce off each other in multi-vehicle fender-benders across Westchester County and northern New Jersey and into the Southern Tier of New York, the police reported.
There were no serious injuries.
Twenty-five cars plowed into each other on one side of Route 3 in East Rutherford, N.J. Minutes later, two five-car pileups occurred directly on the other side of the same highway.

Seventeen cars were involved in a chain-reaction accident in Waldwick, N.J., while 20 cars slammed into each other in Harrison, N.Y. And in Chemung, N.Y., along the Pennsylvania border, a chartered bus full of people visiting relatives in the state prison in Elmira slid off a road, injuring 28 of them.

"The roads iced right up with a fine, misty rain, then it turned to hail and heavy snow," The Associated Press quoted a New York State trooper as saying about the accident in Chemung, which involved a bus chartered from the Cambridge Bus Company that had left New York City early in the morning.

The police later said a driver under the influence of alcohol in a Jeep in front of the bus had skidded out of control while speeding. The bus bounced off the car and through a guard rail. Sharp Temperature Difference
All of those accidents, as well as numerous other one-, two- and three-car mishaps, occurred between 9 and 10:30 A.M.

Bob Stalker, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service at Rockefeller Center in Manhattan, said the big freeze ran along a line north and west of New York City that contrasted with far more moderate readings to the south and east.

"You've got a big range of temperatures," Mr. Stalker said yesterday. "There's a warm front hanging along the coast right now, with temperatures around 45 to 50 degrees. The colder air is north and west.

"Roads are completely iced over," he continued. "We're getting reports about it all the time; from Bergen County, Morris, Passaic, Sussex, Warren" in New Jersey. And in New York, he said, "There are reports of freezing roadways up in Rockland and Westchester."
A Westchester County police communications officer, Nick Autorino, said "seven, eight or nine cars were involved" in an accident on the Saw Mill River Parkway near Tuckahoe Road.
At the New York State police barracks in Hawthorne, Trooper Leon Williams said there had been a 20-car pileup where Interstate Highways 287 and 684 meet in Harrison. 'A 25-Car Hit on Route 3'

A police dispatcher in Passaic County said there had been a five-car accident on Route 21, between exits 10 and 11, and a three-car accident, also on Route 21, near the Van Houten Street overpass in the city of Passaic.

A Bergen County police sergeant, Scott Storms, said, "Besides numerous fender-benders, we had a 25-car hit on Route 3 westbound at the Hackensack Bridge. There were approximately 10 minor injuries and seven to eight vehicles towed from there." That accident was reported at 9:02 A.M.
Minutes later, there were "two five-car hits on the eastbound side," Sergeant Storms said.

An East Rutherford police spokesman, Officer Richard Freeman, said: "The bridge was a sheet of ice when I got there. There were eight or nine cars moved over to the right shoulder; other cars were still either up against the bridge abutment or one another. One car was pretty banged up, all the windows knocked out of it."

Then, about 10 A.M., Sergeant Storms said, 17 cars ran into each other on Route 17 in Waldwick. And other multi-vehicle accidents occurred in Fair Lawn and Glen Rock. "We've got them all over the place," he said.

In Clay, N.Y., a suburb of Syracuse, a Santa Claus on his way to surprise children at a Fire Department Christmas party crashed through the wall in a fire truck, sending cinderblocks flying and terrifying the children.
Eleven people were injured, two of them seriously. The fire truck's driver told authorities that the gas pedal stuck.
